Document Sources.Sourced Statement: The report notes that because L.A. has a 3% floor on annual increases — even in years when the consumer price index is lower — landlords have often been allowed to raise rents above inflation.
Document Sources.Source Justification: a nonprofit research organization the city commissioned to carry out the study

Document Sources.Sourced Statement: The report recommends changes that could lower the rent hikes tenants face each year, setting up what is sure to be a fierce debate at city hall.
Document Sources.Source Justification: a nonprofit research organization the city commissioned to carry out the study

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “What [the report] is trying to do is make a PR effort to lay the groundwork to chip away at what little ability landlords have in L.A. to be able to raise rents and be able to keep up with their costs,” Yukelson said.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: with the Apartment Association of Greater Los Angeles
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: a trade group for property owners

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “Small landlords are able to maintain their profits and draw income above their expenses — they haven't been overly burdened by rent stabilization,” said Christina Boyar, a legal fellow with Public Counsel and a member of the Keep L.A. Housed coalition.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: a legal fellow with Public Counsel and a member of the Keep L.A. Housed coalition
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: a member of the Keep L.A. Housed coalition

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “The cost of electricity is just going to continue going up,” Yukelson with the Apartment Association said.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: with the Apartment Association of Greater Los Angeles
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: a trade group for property owners

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “As we await the finalized version of this report, it’s heartening to see so much data supporting the policy changes that renters have been demanding — especially when it comes to preventing excessive rent increases that can devastate working families.”
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: one of the council members who requested the report be commissioned

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “The Los Angeles ceiling and floor are atypically high for rent-controlled cities,” he said.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: president of the Economic Roundtable and a co-author of the report

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: LAist shared the report with advocates for landlords and tenants.
The National Apartment Association, a trade group for property owners, concluding that California landlords earn 7 cents of profit on average for every dollar of rent.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: a trade group for property owners

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: The Apartment Association of Greater Los Angeles pointed to recent data from the National Apartment Association, a trade group for property owners, concluding that California landlords earn 7 cents of profit on average for every dollar of rent.
Named Organization Sources.Name of Source: Apartment Association of Greater Los Angeles
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: a trade group for property owners
